captions.text:
Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday. I want to
talk today about what's going on in the Central

African Republic, but first a couple prefatory
notes.

One, in the US especially, we tend to image
Africa monolithically as, like, poor and undeveloped

and generally other, even though it is a large
continent full of vastly different nations.

And, while today we are going to talk about
an African state that has struggled more or

less continually since its independence, it's
worth remembering that seven of the world's

ten fastest growing economies are in Africa.
Two, this is speculation, but I think one

of the reasons we don't hear about what’s
going on in the Central African Republic,

is that it's complicated. You know, we like
narratives, like the Rebels versus the Empire,

or Harry versus Voldemort, or Dora versus
Swiper the fox. I'm sorry; I watch a lot of

children's TV. Like, we can stand some shades
of grey in our heroes and our villains, but

we love to know who the heroes are and who
the villains are. And I think a lot of times

when new stories don't fit that narrative,
we just ignore them because the idea of good

guys and bad guys is so central to our understanding
of ourselves and our world that we can't abandon

it. And I also think, if I can tangent on
a tangent, that this is part of why our interest

lags when international news stories grow,
like, less narratively powerful. Like, it's

easy to root for the rebels in Cairo's Tahrir
Square when they want freedom and democracy,

but the actual complex business of rebuilding
a state, as we’ve seen in Egypt and elsewhere,
gets somewhat less attention.

Okay, with all that noted, the Central African
Republic is here in, you guessed it, the centre

of Africa; although, to be fair, it has not
often been much of a republic. Life expectancy

in the CAR is 51 and it's one of the poorest
countries in the world today. So after declaring

independence from France in 1960, there were
several decades of military rule, but then

in 1993, there were multi-party elections,
and the elected president was Ange-Félix

Patassé, and initially, the economy grew
under Patassé, but he failed to be able to

pay the military and civil servants which
is, like, one of the central things that governments

do. Also there was quite a bit of corruption,
and there were several coup attempts over

the next decade. So Patassé remained president
until 2003 when a military coup finally succeeded.

Military leader François Bozizé succeeded
by using the time-honored tactic of waiting

until the president was out of town and then
quickly seizing the government.

So obviously the CAR has long struggled with
security and political stability, like in

the east of the country, the Lord's Resistance
Army, led by Joseph Kony whom you might remember

from his brief moment of 'Kony 2012' internet
fame. Yeah, that guy. His group has been murdering

and torturing people for decades. In fact,
it's believed by many that Kony is hiding

out in the Central African Republic. But also,
both the Patassé and Bozizé regimes relied

on foreign armies from Chad and the Democratic
Republic of Congo and elsewhere to help, like,

shore up their governments. But, security-wise,
after Bozizé took power in 2003, things got

significantly worse. So there was this group,
the Union of Democratic Forces for Unity that

combined with other rebel groups and began
to fight against Bozizé's regime in what

came to be known as the Central African Bush
War. This involved lots of groups, like the

People's Army for the Restoration of Democracy,
and the Convention of Patriots for Justice

and Peace, but anyway, they all banded together
and tried to take down the government. It

didn't work. Finally there was a peace treaty
in 2007, but the fighting never, like, totally
stopped.

Okay, so flash forward to 2012: several of
the groups from the Central African Bush War

unite with some other rebel groups to form
Séléka which means 'union.' And most members

of Séléka belong to the CAR's Muslim minority
which is about 15% of the country's population.

They quickly take control of a bunch of towns
in the north and the centre, and then other

African countries, including Chad, send in
troops to try to protect the capital of Bangui.

But it doesn't work, so in March 2013, the
capital of the Central African Republic, Bangui,

falls to the Séléka rebels, and Bozizé
flees the country. And one of Séléka's leaders,

a Muslim, Michel Djotodia, becomes president,
but almost as soon as Séléka takes power,

there's a lot of in-fighting among all of
these groups that formed the union; like,

it's easy to unify when you're all battling
the government, but then when you have the
power, everybody kinda wants some of the power.

Meanwhile, there was never anything approaching
peace, and Séléka militias committed all

kinds of atrocities. Like, according to Human
Rights Watch, they burned dozens of towns

and villages, they shot fleeing civilians
in the back, and also a huge percentage of

the population has been displaced. There are
tens of thousands of Christians who’ve fled

to the Bangui airport and have remained there
for months. And now we come to the Christian

anti-balaka, or anti-sword militias. These
anti-balaka groups have sought to respond

to Séléka’s violence with much more violence,
and the anti-balaka mass murder of members

of the Muslim minority is now being called
by many a genocide or at least the beginning

of one. So in January 2014, President Djotodia
resigned and was replaced by a woman named

Catherine Samba-Panza, but there isn’t currently
much of a government to lead in the Central

African Republic. Last week, the UN approved
and 11,000 member security force that will

hopefully bring an end to the violence, but
for now it continues.

Hank, like I said earlier, this conflict is
difficult and complicated. It looks nothing

like, you know, Hobbits versus Sauron. But
that isn’t only the case in the Central

African Republic. I mean who were the good
guys in the American Revolution? The Americans

were for freedom and democracy, right? Well
yeah, except for slaves who probably would

have been much better off under the rule of
England. Or what about the Vietnam War or

the French Revolution or World War One in
which so many people died for so little? Hank,

we can’t just ignore stories that don’t
fit our understanding of the world and we

also shouldn’t try to, like, change them
to make them fit our preconceived narratives

of humanity. We have to make room in our stories
for the world as we find it. And the Central

African Republic reminds us that war is not,
finally, a story of good versus evil as much

as we might wish it were so. Let’s hope
the UN peacekeepers arrive soon and can live
up to their name. I’ll see you on Friday.

comments.author: Connor Kelly

comments.text:
I kind of blame the push for rapid decolonization. There was enormous 
pressure from the UN to decolonize so the countries with colonies let go on 
most it's colonies extremely quickly. What that did not allow them to do 
was decolonize in a way to provide for a stable and secure government in 
each colony, and to settle disputes in a more peaceful manner than if say 
each independent country had an army and fought against each other, the 
colonizers army made sure that no one from either side of a dispute fought 
each other, and each side had to come peacefully to accept a solution. They 
also would have been able to build modern infrastructure, like wells, 
hospitals, running water, schools, roads, railways, and utilities. This 
would have made coups less likely, dictators not being able to rise as 
easily because the government in place had experience and knowledge of how 
to peacefully and fairly run a country, and there being checks against the 
military. When the British had to leave Nigeria, only a dozen or so people 
had college degrees. That is not enough to run a country well. The 
colonizers also could have used a system like the Brits with their 
dominions. The countries have some autonomy at first, then as they get 
experience governing, they get some more autonomy, and then more as they 
prove they will not use their autonomy to do things like fight other 
countries for any reason other than to glorify a prime minister, or change 
their constitution to make say women in the 1960s not able to vote. Then 
finally, once the country in question has enough experience, infrastructure 
and development, and has adopted human rights treaties and other needed 
treaties, like membership into the UN, or between themselves and 
neighbouring countries over common issues, they can have a patriated 
constitution. ﻿
comments.author: restlesswikiinfo

comments.text:
Reminder that the warbands John called Christian do not self identify as 
such with a large animist mix. The Lord's Resistance Army does self 
identify as Christian, but I sincerely believe self identification is not 
always helpful in religion or ideologies, al-Qaida isn't truly Muslim, 
China isn't truly Communist, and these supposed Christian groups aren't 
really Christian. We know this because we know objectively what each of 
those are.﻿

comments.author: DamusNostril

comments.text:
Thank you for providing a precise and insightful video that is quick but 
true to what has been taking place in CAR. I spent 10 mths there 20 years 
ago and have watched it decline through decades of corruption and 
mismanagement. It has been difficult over those years to find information 
on the situation there. I remember when I first returned home it was almost 
impossible but with the advent of the internet it has helped a great deal. 
Twitter and Facebook have helped publicize the plight and seriousness of 
the situation. There are those of us who spent time in CAR ie ex peace 
corp, Marines, diplomats etc that are doing our best to spread the word and 
draw international attention to CAR and it's crisis. #CARcrisis  is a good 
hashtag to look up on Twitter if you are interested. Thanks again, Merci! ﻿

comments.text:
I’m wondering if anyone can help me.  I’m looking for the name of the UN 
spokesperson for the United States who told the CAR representative, “You’re 
going to pay for that.”  When the USA went to the United Nations in 2003 to 
try to get backing for its invasion of Iraq the representative for the 
Central African Republic voted against the proposed USA invasion.  Angered 
at this act of insubordination, a USA UN spokesperson sidled over to the 
CAR representative, and unaware that the microphone was still on, hissed at 
him, “You’re going to pay for that!” Fast forward to 2004: Jean-Bertrand 
Aristide ousted in a 2004 U.S.-backed coup; Aristide claims that his 
departure was a kidnapping by the U.S and we know he was then flown 
directly out of Haiti to the Central African Republic.  Payback was pretty 
fast and CAR had no choice but to take Aristide.  If aid was cut off the 
CAR government would have collapsed.  Was it Bolton or Grenell who made the 
threat to CAR?﻿

comments.text:
Not only was WWI over nothing, but there was no good or evil really. 
Everyone paints Germany poorly, but all they did was use mustard gas *which 
the allies used as well*. The war ended with millions dead, two of the 
greatest nations in the world falling and a seriously fucked up picture of 
who was "good" and "evil". What did Germany do? Let's observe.

Austria-Hungary starts with a dead Archduke. Germany then replies "we are 
outraged that someone would kill your representative, please let us protect 
you if anyone tries to join this war". Russia mobilizes. Germany goes "wtf 
Russia? you want to go?" Russia is like "nonono... we aren't landgrabbing 
it isn't like that. We are just scared. Seriously. We really want none of 
your good land." Germany is obviously like "bullshit" (but they wanted 
Russian land too). They mobilize because they actually have a reason to be 
scared. When the Russians reach the border the war starts.

Then France is like "Oh hey Germany. You remember that whole HRE thing? 
Yeah, payback is a bitch huh? War time!" Germany is in strife. They are 
surrounded. They have a weak ally. So they try the Blitz. Unfortunately 
Belgium was like "Get off my lawn!" and like the stupid old man they are 
they stopped the German advance for just long enough. Then England was like 
"wow, why would you invade Belgium you dicks (cough we want your land too 
cough)" and they joined.

No one was a good guy. They were all just warring so they could stamp a 
bigger name on a map.﻿

comments.author: Nuggles01

comments.text:
Hi John and/or Hank,
I was just wondering if you could make a video on the current situation in 
Mexico, with the war against the cartels and the violence that was 
generated from that, especially in border cities. My family is from Ciudad 
Juarez, and we live in El Paso. Juarez was named the most violent city in 
the world in 2010 (I may be wrong on the year, but that is when the 
violence was at its worst), while El Paso is considered the safest big city 
in the United States. With Latinos being one of the largest minorities, 
it's so relevant to people in the US, but its constantly ignored in 
mainstream media. It's like you say, that people like a simple narrative 
when it comes to the news but this situation is complex and multifaceted 
and so important that it deserves attention, and the United States plays a 
part just as much as Mexico and other Latin American countries in this 
issue, and instead of treating drug abuse as the public health issue that 
it is, it's criminalized. Ciudad Juarez used to be a city full of life and 
color, but after 2006 it changed so drastically, so quickly. I don't know, 
I'm just tired of hearing this issue be ignored, when clearly drugs are so 
ingrained in our society, and I'm tired of hearing about a relative's 
relative being murdered. Mexico's gotten a bad rep because of this, but the 
incredible resilience of our people and culture continues to remind me of 
the hope that there is to be had.
I really hope that you read this, and help raise awareness for the 
thousands who have died as a result of the drug war. I thank you so much 
for your awesomeness, which you never forget to be. ﻿
comments.author: Karen De Anda

comments.text:
With subjects like this, I truly believe it's best to let them sort it out 
for themselves. Meaning just education and aid. Every situation is slightly 
different, like every medical patient is unique. It has to be treated on a 
case to case basis. In this country, I'd like to see more states doing 
their own thing with less pressure from the fed govt to adapt to what they 
say is correct. Unless the change is internal, it won't be change. Think of 
a child being told what to do, they do it but they hate you for it. There 
will be resentment. They have to decide how they want to treat the 
situation. All we can do is advise and send aid (ie food and medicine) and 
hope for the best. Is it perfect? Oh god no. But it's freedom of choice. ﻿

comments.author: Deric Jones

comments.text:
Re: Ignoring stories
Are you referring to the media or the American public? Because if it's the 
public, I think the people who follow the news don't necessarily ignore 
these stories, but they don't inspire people to get up in arms about 
anything, because, like you said, there's no solution to or even 
understanding of what's going on. It's a complicated situation that lends 
itself to ambivalence and inertia for this reason. If it's the media you're 
referring to, I agree that there should be more focus, because it's 
journalism that helps bring whatever clarity can be brought to the issue, 
so at least we know enough to know we don't know enough. Unfortunately, 
like any for-profit business, media companies are somewhat beholden to 
financial interests, and their product follows the customer. And so goes a 
vicious cycle...﻿

comments.author: Sarah Haney

comments.text:
I spent 3 weeks in CAR in 2009, it was hot and unpleasant. The economy is 
basically owned by mobile companies with Orange having the largest stake. 
The government (at the time) introduced a flat rate system for all 
providers and made lots of profit from it. At the time I didn't  have a 
visa to get in to the country so a few bribes helped, after I was given a 
signed visa that lasted 30 days from the minister of telecommunications. 
The media coverage has a lot to do with the corporations operating there. 
in Bangui the electricity is switched off around 9AM until about 5:00PM 
with intermittent outages in the evening. The general population don't 
fight and are disaffected because they are just too poor, I didn't see an 
actual house only shanty town style dwelling built from whatever they could 
find.﻿
comments.author: timobb

comments.text:
I think the main reason the news doesn't cover hugely complicated news 
stories is...well...they're hugely complicated. News is about covering 
recent events, in a tumultuous place, the significance of any single event 
is debatable. This makes it difficult to say what's news worthy and what's 
not. 

There's also the issue of time. While in-depth analysis is wonderful, not a 
lot would get covered in a 15-minute news bulletin if every story required 
a history lesson. 

Plus, the risk of accidental bias. If I were a journalist for a respected 
and impartial news broadcaster (i.e. not FOX or MSNBC) then I would be a be 
daunted over the prospect of giving balanced coverage over events in a 
country I know little about on short notice. ﻿
comments.author: Merry Machiavelli

comments.author: Magnus Nygaard

comments.text:
The problem with African countries was the hasty move from colonialism to 
independence(In my opinion). If you have very little idea of what 
independence entails and are subsequently forced to take up a form of rule 
where historically there has been no single leader of an area much greater 
than what a tribe can control a centralised government can't work. 
Independence left the majority of African "states" with very little way of 
dealing with their independence (the voting population are at the mercy of 
their politicians who tell them who to vote for and give them no better 
reason than claiming it is their right to rule the country). This worked 
well enough when the rulers had limited resources and power due to the size 
of the land and the number of people they ruled. Genocide just couldn't 
happen because it was a physical impossibility, but then give those same 
men much more resources, land and people to rule over and the whole way 
they think has to change, but it doesn't. They continue to think of the 
interests of their tribe and consider outsiders a threat, which they are 
because all the many groups of outsiders believe that they are superior. So 
what do humans do when encountering a threat? They exterminate it. Thus we 
have numerous instances of genocide since African states gained their 
independence. So what's the solution? Education. Africans need to begin to 
see themselves as not members of tribes but of "countries" and this can 
only happen when there is an ideological shift and this is what education 
needs to achieve. Will this happen? Not while the "countries" face so much 
turmoil, and as you can see we have a catch 22 situation. No stability in 
Africa without education, no education without stability. ﻿
comments.author: Alan Klein

comments.text:
This is basically (as you said it's complicated but still this is what it 
boils down to) bad guys fighting bad guys to accomplish bad things in a bad 
land all the while innocent civilians are getting killed in the crossfire. 
The only only logical thing we can do (you know other than doing nothing) 
is to go there, ask who doesn't want to fight anybody anymore, fly them to 
the US (to live happily ever after) and let the bad guys continue to kill 
each other. Getting further involved than that and we will just make things 
worse no matter how good our intentions are.﻿

comments.text:
I have a question. Is corruption and destruction of morals and values,etc. 
being aided by our inability to deal with a (bad) good guy and a (good) bad 
guy situation? For example do people tend to disregard their duties more 
when they become aware of the conflicting nature of good and bad?﻿
comments.author: Zackyzic

comments.text:
The reason CAR is ignored in the mainstream media has little to do with it 
being complicated. I would argue that there are two main reasons: 
1) CAR has little financial and strategic value to Western countries i.e. 
the recent conflict does not affect Western interests either militarily or 
economically. 
2) CAR is in a part of the world that is far removed from the lives of 
westerners. Studies show that when two groups of people have fewer personal 
and cultural ties they tend to be less empathetic towards one another. ﻿

the whole country is fragmented in villages e tribes; the concept of 
"central government" or "republic" as we know in the west is totally 
foreign and doesn't apply. What is called the "government" in CAR is the 
control of the Capital city, foreign relations and the army. The rest of 
the country is more connected with local warlords and tribal chiefs than to 
"The Man".﻿
